newsitem.title: USA: Freeze damage to Kansas HRW wheat undetermined.
newsitem.headline: Freeze damage to Kansas HRW wheat undetermined.

text.p: Unseasonably cold weekend temperatures raised concern of freeze damage to Kansas' winter wheat crop, but the extent of damage is currently unknown, the state's agricultural statistics service said on Monday in its weekly crop weather report.
"Temperatures dropped to the single digits on (April) 12th and mid-teens on the 13th, well below the range at which freeze damage can occur," the report said.
The report said most of the damage would have occurred in the southern areas of the state where more wheat had jointed and snow was lacking.
Fifty percent of the state's wheat acreage was said to be jointing, versus seven percent last year and the five-year average of 38 percent.

As of April 13, the wheat condition was rated eight percent excellent, 55 good, 28 fair, eight poor and one very poor. Last week it was rated 22 percent excellent, 60 percent good, 16 percent and two percent poor.
Corn planting was currently four percent complete, slightly behind 1996 and the average of five percent. Corn planting was most advanced in southeast Kansas.
